title: Will Félix Tshisekedi cease to be president of the Democratic Republic of the Congo before 15 August 2020?
preds: Reconfirmin forecast. Not going to happen before aug 15.
Not going to happen within the time frame of this question.
5 days to get hit by a meteorite....

Seems to be little to no reports of action against Tshisekedi across social media and traditional media.  Any demonstrations against Tshisekedi seem to have low participation. The only remaining options for cessation are far too close to 0.

It appears that he cannot be removed by democratic means, he is not going to resign which leaves the option of an involuntary removal.
He has promoted a new head of security that is probably wise given the fates of his predecessors and  announced the end of the Covid-19 pandemic.
His perceived victory over the pandemic might buy some time and avoid any immediate removal. https://worldin.economist.com/article/17368/edition2020instability-top-congo  https://www.theafricareport.com/27207/drc-meet-felix-tshisekedis-new-head-of-security/  https://www.rfi.fr/en/africa/20200722-drc-president-signals-end-of-covid-19-health-emergency-urges-continued-caution
Nothing says or gives an inkling of this occurring.

Doubt he will be democratically removed, but there is always a chance he won't be able to perform the duties. With a pandemic, ebola, and large amounts of upheaval and unrest in the region, there is no such thing as a sure bet over two weeks out.
Always a chance with the virus running around

Only 7 weeks left, no news about legal, health or political issues.

"The Democratic Republic of Congo’s high court sentenced the president’s chief of staff to 20 years of hard labour for the theft of tens of millions of dollars of public money in a landmark case that has captivated the central African nation ... Mr Kamerhe, a former speaker of the national assembly who ran for president in 2011, was a presidential candidate in 2018 before he withdrew and backed Mr Tshisekedi in a deal that would have seen him run as the ruling party’s pick in 2023 ... The conviction effectively ends that arrangement, since it leaves Mr Kamerhe no longer eligible to run for head of state again ... Stephanie Wolters, senior research fellow at the South African Institute of International Affairs, said it was interesting, given the 'ample evidence' of corruption in the former regime, that Mr Tshisekedi had allowed a member of his own coalition to be prosecuted but not yet any member of Mr Kabila’s group. Mr Tshisekedi has sought to win domestic and international support by promising to crack down on the graft and impunity that has long hobbled Congo’s development ... The failure of many of the infrastructure projects undertaken as part of Mr Tshisekedi’s plans for his first 100 days in office had also meant that someone needed to held responsible, Ms Wolters added." https://www.ft.com/content/9f671621-0ce6-4bf6-a16e-2423753cd5a5

All the attention continues to be on the graft probe of Tschisekedi's chief of staff, Kamerhe, whose final verdict is due on the 20th [1]. There is some indication that  the parliament is inching up on him by removing the vice-president of the general assembly, who is an ally of Tschisekedi, though the ousting seems less related to politics and more related to personality [2]. Maintaining my current forecast, as it seems little has changed that would impact Tschisekedi's position. Félix Tshisekedi is only the third present of DRC, with previous administrations lasting 3 and 17 years, respectively. There is no indication that his administration will end prematurely in the next two months.

There is a graft probe against his chief of staff, and some possibility of his coalition breaking down based on this arrest [1]. Though the loss of the coalition does not appear to have much impact outside of the election. Additionally, Tschisekedi seems to be doubling down on anti-corruption, by bringing in Muna, an opposition leader in Cameroon and a transparency advocate [2]. This leads me to believe that any removal from office will be slow moving, if coming at all, and most likely not happening before August. Too hard to trigger a political crisis now, and too easy for a politician to use COVID 19 as an excuse to surpress any protests or discourage change in government at a critical moment

There is a tradition of bad leadership in a number of african countries, including Kongo. Leadership is based on power. Liasing with Kabila means there is no available power to force Mr. Tshisekedi out.
President since January 2019. Only maybe because of Covid19. https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/F%C3%A9lix_Tshisekedi

"Vital Kamerhe, the chief of staff to the president of Democratic Republic of Congo, was arrested on Wednesday after testifying in an investigation into the alleged misappropriation of public funds, police said...Kamerhe’s arrest was a blow to President Felix Tshisekedi, who took power in January last year after campaigning on promises to clean up corruption...Tshisekedi has touted his efforts to root out endemic corruption in Congo, but activists have criticised his government’s spending on a $304 million public works programme as lacking transparency...Kamerhe’s Union for the Congolese Nation (UNC) party joined forces with Tshesekedi’s Union for Democracy and Social Progress (UDPS) in the run-up to the December 2018 election. Tshisekedi promised to back the UNC’s candidate in the next election in 2023...The arrest could cause the collapse of the coalition, but that may have already been in the cards, said Jason Stearns, director of the Congo Research Group at New York University." https://www.reuters.com/article/us-congo-justice/congo-presidents-chief-of-staff-arrested-amid-graft-probe-idUSKCN21Q33L

Outside View: Only one head of state of DRC has been in office for less than two years, Antoine Gizenga, which some consider him to have never been the leader. Inside View: first peaceful transition of power in DRC since independence. Tshisekedi was able to form a government in August of 2019, also a positive sign for him. Lastly he's recognized by the African Union, United States and UN as the leader of the DRC.

Being late to the game, I'll start with a conservative forecast. Nevertheless, there are some things that need mentioning here. Tshisekedi plays a dangerous game with his own countries' military [1]. He can't push them too hard, even if he coordinates his actions closely with former president Kabila as a means to appease US interests and receive funding [1, 2]. The effects of Covid-19 are to be seen. Kinshasa is under lockdown [3, 4]. The health system is not capable of dealing with high infection rates [5].  What does this all mean for Tshisekedi? Probably that nothing will happen. I do not expect that Kabila or the military will oust Tshisekedi before the epidemic is over as it provides them with a good argument to get rid of him if his Corona responses are seen as insufficient [6]. Will the outbreak end before August 15 in the DRC? Maybe, not likely, but the particularities will concern the upcoming forecasts. Toggling to 1 based on no new data, but not clear how covid-19 will impact a country that has managed to survive ebola for years. Currently, 30 cases.

So far, Félix Tshisekedi still maintains a power-sharing agreement with Joseph Kabila (the former president of the DRC).  Apparently, that deal is under strain.  Kabila currently controls a two-thirds majority in parliament. Under Tshisekedi, the Congolese government has introduced free primary education and undertaken infrastructure building and rehabilitation.  Since the DRC's domestic revenues were not sufficient to cover these expenses, the country's central bank (BCC) made monetary advances to the government.  This move has eroded the DRC's international reserves to low levels. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) met with Congolese officials on November 6 -15, 2019.  Due to the monetary and economic issues the DRC is facing, the IMF and the Congolese government reached an agreement that would be supported by Rapid Credit Facility (RCF, an IMF program that provides financial assistance with limited conditions to low-income countries).  This RCF is being monitored by IMF staff until May 2020.  Usually, it seems that whenever a country implements conditions imposed by the IMF, governments or heads of states loose power or a overthrown. It may appear that the spending the Congolese government made was to appease the people.  The government may want to appease its people because not much has changed in the DRC since Tshisekedi became president.  Economic growth is expected to drop in 2020.  Although Tshisekedi has a deal with Kabila, the two of them don't get along very well.  To deal with the COVID-19 outbreak, the Congolese government has enacted measures similar to other countries in the world. I believe that Félix Tshisekedi will remain president of the DRC for all of 2020.  However, there is a possibility he may not remain president in 2021. Depending on the way events unfold, I may have to change my forecast. Sources: http://www.rfi.fr/fr/afrique/20200226-rdc-bilan-demi-teinte-premi%C3%A8re-mission-fmi https://www.imf.org/en/News/Articles/2019/11/15/pr19421-drc-and-imf-mission-reach-agree-ad-ref-on-fa-under-rcf-and-staff-monitored-program https://worldin.economist.com/article/17368/edition2020instability-top-congo

The probability he is no longer the president is based on probability of death.  There would have to be drastic changes in international strategic interests causing foreign pressure for him to resign that would be greater than the incentives for him to stay.  The probability of coupe is very low when leaders in Africa are fearful of a coupe because they are vigilant to instigators and the power of their subordinates.  At this point his is trying to solidify power, and in the DRC that is defined by who controls the capital.  Military action by other state actors is improbable, especially since there is a UN peacekeeping mission in both DRC and CAR which consists of participants from many of the nations who would have to be involved in such action.

Unless Kabila wants him gone, there is not threat to his presidency regardless of the social-economic realities of the DRC.
Unless he dies in power.

Tshisekedi's budget was rejected by parliament, which will make it impossible to meet his pledge on free primary education. Neither of these are likely to threaten his power in the short term. My previous 20% estimate was probably too high, so reducing slightly but not too much to reflect ongoing volatility.

Late to this question, but will jump on anyway, because it's a domain where I have some expertise. There are a just a handful of ways a leader can exit office: natural death, successful assassination, resignation, lost election, successful revolution, or successful coup.
* Lost election: no presidential election scheduled this year, so p ~ 0.
* Natural death: Tshisekedi is only 56, so p(dying of natural causes in the next six months) < 0.01.
* Successful assassination: extremely rare in recent history, so p ~ 0.
* Resignation: already weathered the post-election storm, so this would require a Black Swan scenario, so p < 0.01.
* Successful revolution: this is the kind of Black Swan scenario I just mentioned. Base rate in authoritarian regimes is extremely low in recent decades, so, again p < 0.01 on a six-month time horizon.
* Successful coup: One Earth Future Foundation's CoupCast puts the probability of a coup attempt in DRC in 2020 at about 0.01. Their model is state of the art, so I'll just use that. In the post-Cold War period, coup attempts have succeeded roughly half of the time, so that gets us pretty close to 0 on this front, too. That's a lot of < 0.01s, so I'm going to sum them to 0.02. Will increment downward in a few months if no relevant news. Will consider adjusting marginally upward if we see events in the news that suggest a coup attempt or sustained protest movement is brewing or has occurred.

Whether or not Tshisekedi maintains power in the DRC depends primarily on his relationship with Kabila, but also on popular opinion and the weight of humanitarian events such as the conflict in Kivu and the presence of Ebola.  With that said, it is unlikely that he will cease to be president by August 2020; Kabila’s influence remains strong and it is nearly impossible for Fayulu or anyone else to challenge that.  As long as Tshisekedi does not diverge too far from Kabila’s will, and as long as there is no major disagreement or falling out between the two men, Kabila has no reason to seek a replacement for Tshisekedi (and risk potential truths about his role in the election becoming confirmed by the general population).

Tshisekedi's appointment was clearly illegitimate, but that doesn't mean he won't stay in power. First Mobutu and then the Kabilas stayed in power for decades. He has done a coalition deal with supporters of the Kabila dynasty . He seems to have established good relations with neighbouring Rwanda and Uganda who might have intervened to unseat him if they felt he threatened their interests. Martin Fayulu (who actually won the election) has called protests but I don't see how they would be enough to unseat Tshisekedi. There is human tragedy with people being killed by militias in the east of the country but again there's no particular link between that and regime change. Initially selecting 20% which is relatively high for a 7-month window, due to a) DRC being a relatively unstable country and b) my ignorance, which I hope to reduce.
Things against him are mounting up, and will soon reach critical mass
He seems to be on good footing by negotiating with opposition and by having international support. Do not see negativity about him on twitter or in the news. He is relatively new so have to recheck.

Tshisekedi has proven to be an adept deal-maker and consummate politician.  Since his swearing in a year ago (January 2019) he has been able to negotiate a deal with the parliament on the formation of a new government which divides the ministries between the Kabila-aligned FCC and Tshisekedi's CACH alliance.  This ability to develop solutions will permit him to serve the full length of his 5 year term and to stand for reelection
Unless something drastic happens, it's not likely going to happen.
